label: Description
value: Top row, two anchored barges shown obliquely from the sterns. Center, a barge sailing toward right, with Dutch colors. Bottom, three anchored barges shown from the sterns. Verso: sketches in graphite of a mast and barge.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite, brush and watercolor on illustration board

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet tipped vertically into binding.  Depicted is a half-timbered and plaster building seen from the rear.  The building is raised up on a plain, masonry lower level, and is then divided by a large sill on which sits the half-timbered story.  The timbering is patterned like arrows.  Smoke swirls out of the short chimney stack.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on off-white paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet depicting five sketches of buildings or architectural details in Coucy-le-Château including the corner of a Renaissance house, a dormer, a well head with decorative ironwork, a pulley, and the date 1776 written in iron ties.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet tipped vertically into binding depicting a very lightly sketched view of the towers of Château de Coucy.  The château appears to sit up on a hill with very little vegetation in front of it.  Trees are visible at the rear of the castle.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on gray paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
Two Views of Belfry, Hotel de Ville, Coucy-le-Château

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating two views of the belfry of the Hotel de Ville in Coucy-le-Château.  The mansard roof has two small louvered dormers below the clock tower above.  A small turret with faceted roof is visible to one side.  A very small drawing of a chimney is at the top of the sheet between the two larger drawings below.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet depicting above a round masonry tower buttressed on the left side and with a pitched, crocketed spire behind it.  Below is a view through a large masonry gate into a streetscape.  The pointed arch opening is buried within the base of the walls of stair towers on either side.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet tipped vertically into binding.  Seen from a distance is a large tower in the center of a low, forested and built landscape of small buildings.  The tower is round with an arcaded uppermost story.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet depicting six sketches of architectural elements and ornament.  At top left is a spire with an octagonal cupola and finial.  At the top right is a dormer that greatly overhangs the window below and is supported by two brackets mounted to either side of the window.  Below this ia another dormer that overhangs and is supported by a row of three brackets above the windows.  Below left is another dormer that overhangs, although the bottom is canted back and the trusses are visible on the underside.  Finally at lower left is another example of a roof overhang visibly supported by brackets underneath.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on thick cream wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet that has been cut down, but centered vertically in the binding.  Depicted are four different scenes of ships on the water.  Three scenes show boats that are in various points of the water, both near and far.  The smallest at left shows a large vessel being pulled by a tugboat.  At bottom left is a sailboat with H.20 painted twice on the starboard side of her hull.  The sails also are identified with the same lettering: 20 / (anchor symbol) / H.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on thick cream wove paper tipped into binding with fabric
Houses on Rue de la Concorde, Havre

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet cut down at the top and mounted centrally in the binding.  Depicted are the corners of two blocks with a small alley between them.  The buildings are late medieval or Renaissance in origin with later additions.  They are masonry at the first story with timber above.  The rooflines are irregular, punctuated by windows with large dormers and many chimney stacks. The street level of the building at the write is labeled EPICERIE DUVAL SP....

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on thick cream wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating four sketches of architectural details or ornament.  At top left is the octagonal cupola of a cathedral tower with louvered openings on two levels, capped by a dome with dormers and a finial.  To the right is a bird of prey clutching a snake or serpent in its claws standing on a ball finial.  Below this is the top of a clock tower with a trio of bells hung from an ironwork structure above.  Two scrolling brackets decorate the ironwork on either side.  Below left is another tower with an octagonal cupola though here with an ogee curve and a cross at the apex.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on thick cream wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet depicting a large, medieval masonry structure with many later Renaissance and Baroque additions.  The mass of the building on the right is only sketched so as to understand its volume, while the section of the building at left has been fully rendered to capture the details of the rusticated stonework, the arched entrance and wood doors, a canon, and the irregularities of the roofline with its chimneys and turrets.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on thick cream wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet depicting a small early Baroque church seen from the west.   The west facade has a semicircular portico with a small clock tower above.  Above the tower is a niche with a statue of a woman holding a child on her left hip. Given the statue's location and the dedication of the church to the Virgin Mary, it is likely a staute of Mary holding Christ on her hip.  The tower is completed by small cupola and finial in the shape of a rooster.  Visible beyond the west entrance are the two buttressed arms of the nave, and small round arched windows of the aisles.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream papeboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical rectangle containing three sketches: above, a half-timbered building partially supported by a rusticated stone arch is seen at an angle.  The timbering is laid in intricate intersecting patterns, all unique. Below this at left and right are two different types of wood-supported spans.  The one at the right is a very straightforward bracket consisting of two pieces of wood intersecting at a 90-degree angle; the one at left is a detail of the arch in the sketch above.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on blue paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet depicing four sketches of steeples or roofs of buildings.  At top right is a square timbered building with irregular roof dormers that do not match.  The dormer over an oval window opening is drawn again in greater detail below, showing the dormer's prominent spike finial.  To the left of this is the drawing of a Gothic tower ending in a tall steeple ornamented with crockets and twin crosses at its apex.  Below this is a drawing of a steeply pitched roof, its gable covered by wooden timbers creating a pointed arch, with a balcony along the lowest row of windows. At bottom left is a tower with three levels ov eaves, and the roof with a large, overhanging dormer on the right side.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on thick cream wove paper tipped into binding with fabric
Details of Roofs and Gables, Rouen

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating four sketches of dormers, roofs, and gables.  In the upper left of the sheet is a drawing of a gabled roof whose left side has an irregular flare out at the eave.  Over two windows is a small canopy supported by timbers from underneath.  At right is a gabled roof with a pointed wooden arch  framing a row of windows that are shielded by a canopy above.  To the right of this is a small sketch of the bottom of a chimney showing it supported by two brackets from underneath.  At lower left is a sketch of a dormer with a large overhang supported by two curved brackets on either side of the window frame, and a small decorative finial above.  At lower right is the upper part of a structure that has a loggia with three openings shielded by the eave above which is supported by timber brackets.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on gray paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
Staircase, Cloister of St. Maclou, Rouen

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet depicting a late medieval or early Renaissance era half-timbered and plastered building.  At left a simple, covered staircase rises to the second floor.  The staircase casts a deep shadow along an adjacent opening at the first floor.  To the right and above this are rows of windows set into flattened arches, each with a prominent keystone.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on gray paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
Bow and Stern of Trireme with Details

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet depicting a Roman trireme (warship).  The upper half of the sheet depicts the bow of the ship, with a tall angular hull with a pointed, curved prow, similar to a duck's bill.  The upper section is crenellated, projecting over the port side of the hull, upon which has been painted a fierce eye and brown.  Further behind this is a deck opening enclosed by a cross-beam railing.  The hull has small portholes, and three oars visible below.  To the firth of this is a sketch of the masthead.  The lower half of the sheet shows the ship's stern which curves up and over the top of the end of the ship.  There is another opening to the deck enclosed by a cross-timbered railing with oars projecting from the wooden hull below.  To the right of this is a small sketch of the interior of the ship, depicting in section the dugout-like seats for the rowers.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on gray paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating examples of bronze hardware found on vases, tables, and desks, all in the Louis XVI style.  At the top is a rose leaf festoon tied together with a ribbon in a soft cream color.  Below is a very large medallion framed by bow of laurel leaves and berries bound together at the top and a large golden yellow ribbon in imitation of gilt bronze above.  At bottom right are two bows of a garland, its floral elements stylized, all tied to a central medallion with two ribbons streaming out of it from either side.  Below left is an escutcheon in the shape of two crossed laurel branches tied with a neat bow at the base, which frames the key hole.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor, graphite on off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric
Architectural Details from Orleans, Metalwork from Blois

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet divided into an upper and lower half. The upper half depicts architectural elements from buildings in Orleans, while the lower half illustrates an example of an iron door latch and detail of its finial.  At upper left is a canopied well head, its round basin seen with a hand crank on the left for raising and lowering a basket into the well.  The canopy above is ogee-formed with a small finial above, and supported by two ironwork brackets on either side.  The drawing at right shows an arched door opening with a projecting cornice above supported by a herm in the Mannerist style, shown in profile to the right.  Below center is a ironwork latch rendered in 1/2 scale, made of flat pieces of iron side by side ending at top and bottom with double fleur-de-lys finials.  To the right is a full-size detail of the finial element, and to the left, a profile of the latch's knob. Slotted, flat-head screws are used throughout.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor, graphite on thick cream wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet depicting a tile floor pattern in shades of blue, white and yellow.  At the center is a large capital H in golden yellow on a blue ground made of four tiles, and radiating around this to form a square in the center are four small yellow quatrefoils at the cardinal points, and four tiles with golden yellow fleur-de-lys also on a blue ground at the ordinal points.  This pattern is then surrounded by a blue and white diaper pattern with a tile at the ordinal points repeating the quatrefoil and fleur-de-lys motifs.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor, graphite on thick cream wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Left, two young trees; right, two trees in a meadow shown against wooded hills. Verso, boulders and an evergreen.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite, brush and watercolor on cardboard

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating  a tile floor pattern.  Three bands of alternating brown and blue squares frame the lower right corner of tilework in shades of blue, white, and golden yellow.  The central tiles create a diamond pattern of alternating blue and white diamond-shaped tiles, tiles with a yellow fleur-de-lys on blue ground, and tiles with a yellow rosette and stylized yellow fleurs-de-lys radiating from the cardinal points. The colors are much more muted than those depicted in 1943-51-199.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor, graphite on off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet depicting three sketches of architectural elements of the Château de Fontainebleau.  The upper half of the sheet depicts a tall mansard roof with chimney and a round tower with steep roof and classical dormer to the right.  To the right of this sketch is the letter F, rendered as if made up of masonry segments.  The lower half of the sheet illustrates the clock tower (Tour de l'Horloge) and the pavillon of the Cour de Cheval.  The clock tower is in a very reserved Renaissance style with three stories, each defined by columns at the corners and separated by stringcourses, surmounted by an arcaded cupola and finial.  The pavillion at left is in the French Renaissance style, the two floors dominated by the massive, overscaled mansard roof above.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet depicting a large half-timber and plaster building at left with an enclosed space at the second story that connects to the adjacent structure at right. Under this enclosed space is an open walkway tow a courtyard beyond.  The room has beams underneath which extend to trusses that support it against the walls of the buildings on the left and right.  The facade of the building on the left has a projecting cornice at the second story which is at the same level of the beams supporting the enclosed space.  This cornice is supported below by decorative wooden brackets with a cyma curve.  An example of one of these brackets is drawn at lower left, shown from the front and a profile that is scaled.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
Door with Dragon, Château de Chambord

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet tipped vertically into binding depicting a view of the front and back of a wooden door with a profile of one of its diamond-shaped panels in the center of the sheet.  At left and right are the back and front of the door, respectively.  The upper section of the door shows a recessed diamond frame on which is the serpentine figure of a dragon breathing fire and surrounded by small flames with a crown suspended in the air above its head.  On the front of the door, the dragon faces the right; on the reaf of the door, the dragon faces to the left.  the lower half of the front door has another diamond-shaped panel that mimicks the one above, and scattered within it are more small flame carvings.  Raised, lozenge-shaped panels dominate the lower half of the door at left.  One lozenge has been drawn and is crossed by a line AB.  This line is drawn again in the center of the sheet and is the molding profile of the lozenge carving.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating architectural features from the town of Poissy.  At left is a Gothic tower over the crossing of the church of Collegiale Notre-Dame.  It is in an early Gothic style, heavy with masonry.  The tower rises behind the semicircular apse at the lower level, with an octagonal cupola above.  The cupola has double round-arched openings at the carndinal points, and single arches at the ordinal points.  Each opening has louvers.  Above this rises an octagonal roof and finial.  Above right is the picturesque roofline of another building.  It has two chimneys at different heights, a steeply pitched roof in the front, and a tower to the left with an ogee cupola above. Below right is a very small sketch of a window, dormer and chimney from an unidentified building.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet depicting four sketches of buildings or architectural elements.  The upper half of the sheet has two views of a half-timbered building.  The left drawing shows the building with a masonry first story and half-timber and plaster above.  At right, possibly the same building from the rear. Below is another half-timbered building seen from a three-quarter view.  It has timbering that alternates between straight timbers and those have been carved into an S-shape.  Above is a deep overhang and steep tiled roof.  At right is the steeple of a bell tower, consisting of  a trio of graduated onion domes, and a small finial.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating two sketches of architectural elements.  In the center is the clock tower of the Hôtel de Ville (city hall) of the town of Reims, seen from the south.  The octagonal tower rises from the roofline with multiple graduated arcaded cupolas and is topped by a finial with weathervane.  At bottom right is an unusually intricate dormer.  The dormer projects out from the roof ending in a circle. Underneath this small dome is carved and pierced wood, similar to flamboyent Gothic tracery.  The window opening is framed by two scrolling brackets on either side of the window frame.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet with two sketches of architectural elements.  At left is a short tower rising from a roofline.  The tower has flattened double arches which are louvered, an an ogee cupola faceted steeple with finial and weathervane above.  At right is the corner of a building ending in a gabled roof that has only been partially rendered.  At the corner of the roof is a gutter and turret with a small window, and lower roof with window below it.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
Sketches of Architectural Elements, Blois and Amboise

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrated three sketches of buildings and architectural elements.  At top left is the right staircase tower at the Château de Blois.  It is a Romanesque tower with blind arcade decoration at the uppermost level, topped by a mansard roof with chimney.  At top right is a dormer that far overhangs the window opening below and ends in a curve.  Underneath the dormer has wooden tracery similar to a flamboyant Gothic style.  At bottom right is the corner of a masonry and half-timbered and plastered house.  The half-timbering is only on the upper story, ending with a small tower in the corner.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on thick cream wove paper tipped into binding with fabric
Sketches of Architectural Elements, Loches and Arzay-le-Rideau

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet with five sketches of buildings and architectural elements.  Clockwise from top right is a tiled dormer from Loches. Below this is a small open belfry with a narrow, pitched roof supported on two narrow posts, also from Loches.  Below this is a masonry belfry attached to a round turret supported by stone modillions below.  A bell is visible in the belfry, and it is topped by a cupola with finial flying a flag.  To the left of this is portion of a façade elevation of a masonry building in a late Renaissance style.  The elevation consists of four stories, each of which has a double arcade (door openings at the ground level with windows repeated in the arcade above).  Above this sketch is the elevation of a building exterior with a portico at the second floor from which descends a curved masonry staircase to the ground below.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on thick off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric
Latch Plate and Door Handle from Salle des Etats, Blois

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet with three drawings illustrating door hardware.  At center is a long metal plate ending in a fleur-de-lys at top and bottom, with a modeled rectangular handled and thumb plate.  To the left of this is a small drawing of a key hole.  To the right is a view in plan of the thumb plate shown only in elevation in the drawing at center.  The thumb plate is made up of three small round balls that project from a narrow strip of metal.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor, graphite on thick cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
Door and Hardware, Salle des Etats, Blois

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating scaled drawings of a door and its hardware from the Salle des Etats.  The door is drawn at lower left.  It has three large strap hinges, and a latch which have been executed in watercolor.  Above is a detail of a scrolling metal rest for the door latch, seen from the side and from the front.  To the right of this is a drawing of the latch in plan, with one of its finials also executed in profile above.  To the right of this is one of the strap hinges with four decorative rosette nailheads.  Both the latch and hinge terminate in a fleur-de-lys.  These elements are also drawn perpendicular to the door so as to fit on the page.  At bottom right is one of the nailheads seen in plan, rendered full size.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor, graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating in plan a section of tile flooring near the altar in the chapel at Château de Blois. The outermost set of tiles is rendered in brick red, possibly in imitation of terra cotta.  The next field of tiles consists of alternating blue tiles with yellow fleurs-de-lys and white tiles with small brown ornament.   The next field consists of one row of tiles that are white with a green quatrefoil enclosing gradually smaller quatrefoils in white, brown, and yellow.  Another group of the brick red tiles is at the innermost edge. The scale of the drawing is written below.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor, graphite on off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating tile floor pattern from Chapel at Château de Blois. Many of the tiles here are the same as those seen in 1943-51-212, the drawing of the tile floor near the altar in the same chapel.  The majority of the tilework is brick red, possibly in imitation of terra cotta.  At the top left is a group of nine white tiles with brown ornament.  To the right of this is a row of three white tiles with green, yellow and brown quatrefoils, which is separated by one terra cotta tile, and then repeated.  To the right of this is the beginning of what, one assumes, is another group of the nine white tiles seen at top left.  Below this is a blue shield with three yellow fleurs-de-lys on a white ground which is created by nine tiles.  Above and to the bottom left and right of the shield are yellow rosettes.  At the ordinal points from this group of tiles are white tiles with a dark blue fleur-de-lys, although only the upper left corner tile like this has two small yellow dots on either side of the fleur-de-lys.  The rest of the field of tiles surrounding this section are terra cotta tiles.  To the left is a vertical repetition of the three white tiles with green, brown and yellow quatrefoils seen above.  The scale is given at lower right.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor, graphite on off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric
Window of the Grande Salle, Château de Blois

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating part of a wood framed, leaded glass window.  The leading is patterned with rows of faceted rectangles that have been faintly tinted yellowish green to indicate their opacity.  These are separated by small diamond-shaped panes of glass upon which have been painted (likely in yellow- and silver stain) fleurs-de-lys and a small brown symbol. In the center is a roundel of blue glass that frames a porcupine facing left with a crown above.  Around this field is a double border of decorative glass panes.  The outermost border is of yellow guilloche which is intersected by another border of red glass.  Rendered at bottom left of the frame is a flat decorative hinge that has pierced openings in the shape of a heart.  On the right side of the frame is a pierced bar latch to close the window.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor, graphite on off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric
Cresting on Chapel, Château de Blois

label: Description
value: Square sheet that has been cut down to this size.  Illustrated at top center is a section of cresting from the roof of the chapel of the Château de Blois.  The cresting consists of fleurs-de-lys in blue and gold.  The end of the cresting terminates in a blue and gold finial with decorative metal floral elements springing from the top.  To the right of this is another sketch of decorative metalwork from Blois from a finial on the square tower of the château.  The finial has an octagonal base in blue with gold leaves.  Two seahorses are at either side, with a gold flame-like finial at the top.  To the far left is another section of cresting, this time from the roof of the left tower at Château de Blois.  This cresting has sections of metal that create an x-shape, from which small crockets spring.  Above are gold fleurs-de-lys.  This cresting also ends in a finial with an urn with seahorses for handles, a crown above, and a small banner with three fleurs-de-lys with a crown above, and a final fleur-de-lys at the top of the finial.  The roof of both the chapel and this tower are visible, and both have rows of painted yellow fleurs-de-lys.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor on thick cream wove paper tipped into binding with fabric
Tile Floor, Diane de Poitiers Bedroom, Château de Chaumont

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating plan view of a tiled floor with patterns of tiles in blue, white, yellow, and brick-red (in imitation of terra cotta).  Above this are drawings of each of the eight different types of tiles. They include, from left to right: a blue fleur-de-lys on white ground; two of the letter D interlocked in blue on a white ground with blue corners; a version of the previous tile but only on a white ground with the letters rendered in golden yellow; a yellow Tudor rose with black center on a blue ground; three interlaced blue crescent moons (Borromean rings) with small yellow stars on white ground; one example each of a blue, brick red, and orange red tile.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor, graphtie on off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet that has been cut down.  Illustrated above are four sketches of two dormers; the same one is drawing from the front, side and three-quarter view at left.  Below is a drawing of a large masonry building with a round tower with tall, conical roof and finial in the front, while visible behind it is another shorter tower with two chimney stacks, and the cupola of another tower.  Below to the right of the shorter square tower is a lower crenellated wall ending in a small stair turret.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on thick cream wove paper tipped into binding with fabric
